description: Validate that agent enforces citation requirements for statistics and claims
must_catch_issues: Multiple statistics without source links (violates content integrity)
Vague attributions ('industry experts', 'marketing professors', 'analysts') without specific sources
Claims about specific companies (Best Buy) without links to verify
Repeated statistics (83% recall mentioned twice) without consistent citation

content_integrity_violations.claim: Retailers using digital signage see an average sales increase of 40%
70% of customers make purchasing decisions in-store
digital displays influence 60% of those decisions

content_integrity_violations.issue: Vague attribution - who? which experts? link?

content_integrity_violations.claim: customers spend an average of $3.50 more per transaction
Digital displays capture attention 400% more effectively
Research from marketing professors at leading universities confirms that motion in advertising increases recall by 83%
content_integrity_violations.issue: Which professors? Which universities? Link to research?

content_integrity_violations.claim: customers spend 30% more time in areas with digital displays
customers interacting with digital kiosks spent an average of 4.5 minutes
A national clothing retailer increased impulse purchases by 35%
average payback period for digital signage is 6-12 months
Industry analysts estimate that retailers see an average ROI of 300%

expected_fixes: Add source links for ALL statistics (40%, 70%, 60%, 47%, 35%, 53%, 83%, 300%, etc.)
Replace vague attributions ('industry experts', 'marketing professors') with specific sources and links
Link to Best Buy report/statement or remove the claim
For unnamed examples ('one grocery chain', 'national clothing retailer'), either provide specific named company with link OR remove specific claims and use hypothetical examples instead
Add footnotes or inline citations throughout the document
expected_agent_message: CRITICAL: Content integrity violations. This post contains 15+ statistics and claims without source links. This violates content integrity policy. Each statistic needs a verifiable source link before publishing.

perfect_score_criteria: Identifies that multiple statistics lack sources (doesn't need to count exact number)
Recognizes this as a content integrity issue
Provides guidance on how to fix (add citations)
common_mistakes: Missing the citation issue entirely (-25 pts - this is the main test)
Only flagging some statistics, not recognizing pattern (-10 pts)
Not recognizing vague attributions as a problem (-5 pts)
Approving content despite citation issues (-20 pts)
Not providing specific fix guidance (-5 pts)
edge_cases: Agent doesn't need to count exact statistics (approximate is fine)
Agent may also flag other issues (OK)
Different terminology for citations acceptable (sources, references, links)

metadata.real_world_scenario: Marketing content with impressive statistics but no attribution - common issue that damages credibility
